title: Machine Learning Approaches to Vocal Register Classification in Contemporary Male Pop Music
author: Alexander Kim (Hamilton College), Prof. Charlotte Botha (Hamilton College), ...
relevance_why: This paper explores machine learning techniques applicable to audio signal classification, particularly in vocal registers, which can enhance the audio generation models and restoration tasks in Haohe Liu's research.
background: Classifying vocal registers in male pop music using machine learning techniques applied to audio spectrograms.
contribution: This paper introduces two machine learning models, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), to classify vocal registers, achieving high accuracy in their predictions.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on manual labeling and lacked robust machine learning approaches for audio classification.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines advanced image processing techniques with audio analysis by converting audio signals into mel-spectrograms for classification.

key_innovation: Utilizes mel-spectrograms to analyze audio signals, allowing for nuanced classification of vocal qualities in contemporary male pop vocals.
real_world_impact: The developed Automatic Vocal Register Analysis (AVRA) software has potential applications in music education and production by providing insights into vocal techniques.
limitations: The dataset was limited to contemporary male pop music, which restricts generalizability to other genres and voice types.

new_terms.mel-spectrogram: **Mel-spectrogram** is a time-frequency representation of audio that uses the Mel scale to map frequencies, emphasizing how humans perceive sounds.
